results.title: The Letters
results.creator_credit: Clarry Answerth, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Despite the fact that Clarry Answerth’s mother had such a lonely start to life, she grew into a compassionate woman who would care for those in need.

results.title: Shop 16
results.creator_credit: Shawn Reece, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Shawn Reece had no confidence and stayed at home when he wasn’t at school. That is, until his friend convinced him to come along to Shop 16, a youth centre run by the Salvation Army in Reservoir.

results.title: Just another bump in the road!!!
results.creator_credit: Michelle Carlin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Michelle Carlin loved her job caring for disabled people. It has encouraged her to take a positive outlook on life no matter how much things go wrong and in turn this has helped her through some very tough times.

results.title: Italian settlement in the Yarra Valley
results.creator_credit: Maria McCarthy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Maria McCarthy recalls the stories from her youth, the ones told about her families’ voyage from Italy to Australia and settling in the Yarra Valley. She tells of her parents’ adoption of a new culture and way of life and the legacy of those decisions on the present.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Maria McCarthy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: You really had to be there!
results.creator_credit: Dean Turner, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Dean Turner cherishes the Punk Rock nights at the Arthouse in North Melbourne, where you could drink, hang out and have your five minutes of fame. Poverty is their way of life, but music uplifts them.

results.title: Cyberthon II: The Virtual Transmission [event version]
results.brief_description:
‘Cyberthon II: The Virtual Transmission’ was the second in the series of Cyberthon broadcast events. Set up from TVU’s (Television Unlimited) warehouse and studio in Footscray Victoria, it was once again broadcast live via RMITV’s frequency UHF-31. Unlike the previous Cyberthon and Cyberdelia broadcast events however, Cyberthon II: The Virtual Transmission had expanded in scope afforded by its new venue and increasing popularity of the techno scene.

Adding to the DJ, VJ sets, live performances of electronic music and art, a range of artists also performed live. Artists such as Stelarc performed his Third Arm and Craig Horsham displayed his subversive VHS crash editing of mainstream TV commercials. The Amiga Users Group exhibited a collection of Amiga demos while a diverse range of artists displayed accompanying complex visual effects and art installations.

This is the event version of ‘Cyberthon II: The Virtual Transmission’. For the [1-hour compilation] see title B2004202

Visual Artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Cyber Dada (Dale Nason and Troy Innocent), Future Films (Jeff Jaffers), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton and Attillio Gangemi), Bureau of Inverse Technology - BIT (Natalie Jeremijenko, Kate Rich and Danny Tigani), Amiga Users Group, Craig Horsham, Force Fed (Stuart McCormick & Michael Brand), Video Graffiti (Andrew Nelson)

Audio Artists: Third Eye ‘Ambi Jam’ (Gus Till, Ollie Olsen, Geoffrey Hales, Simon Polinski), Blast Off Sound System (Jason ‘Rudeboy’ Mac), Foil (Neil Boyack, Andrew Coates, Steve Law, Chris Grierson), 1x4x9 (Braden Schlager & Miles du Heaume), Magnetic Head Circuit (Chubba, Matt Bastard, Peter Randall), Tribal (Duncan Gray, Bruce Yardley & Cam Saunderson), Extroversion (Kate Armstrong), Hardware (Richie ‘Rich’ McNeil), Mystic Force (Russell Hancorne), Poets of the Machine (Koral Island & Stripe)

Performers: Stelarc, Just to fresh, Computer Graphture (Simone Millman and Tanya Hoddinott), Space Between The Gaps (Paul Gafney), Jacinta Le Plastrier, Yoga (Mary Galick, Bronwyn Richie & Paul Gafney), Zenep Jaffers

Cyberthon II: The Virtual Transmission is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: My ambitions
results.creator_credit: David Clune, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Since David Clune first travelled to Japan at 16, he developed a thirst for travel that has never been quenched. In all his travels, he has witnessed suffering amongst the beauty and it has encouraged in him a desire to make a difference, even though he is content in Australia…for now.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Clune, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
